intro: Phippsia palustris, commonly known as the swamp phippsia, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to wetland habitats in North America. It typically grows in marshy or boggy areas, where it thrives in moist, acidic soils. The plant features slender, grass-like leaves and produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are often clustered at the base of the stems. It plays a role in stabilizing wetland ecosystems by preventing soil erosion. Due to its specific habitat requirements, it is considered a sensitive indicator of wetland health.
